oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cumberland Gap: City Hall
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van, photographer
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photo of the Cumberland Gap City Hall at the corner of Colwyn Ave. and Cumberland Drive. The two-story building was constructed as the Cumberland Gap Public School in 1925. The building is built on a concrete block foundation with red brick walls, hipped roof with a windowless dormer, and double glass entry doors at the first level. Five six-over-six windows line the upper level and a single window is to the right of the door. A basement level on the left side has a small window and separate entrance. Two flights of concrete stairs lead to the the building from the street.

For over two hundred years, Cumberland Gap has served as a significant passageway to the lands west of the Appalachian mountains. The Cumberland Gap Historic District is significant as evidence to the patterns of Claiborne County's history as a late nineteenth and early twentieth century mining town funded by foreign capitalists as well as its associations with Wilderness Road. American Association, Limited had its headquarters in Cumberland Gap.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cumberland Gap (Tenn.);
